comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: lmo.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luigi_Cadorna a Wikipedia page in the Milanese language/dialect -- see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milanese led me to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luigi_Cadorna "Luigi Cadorna (September 4, 1850, Verbania, Piedmont-Sardinia – December 21, 1928) was an Italian Field Marshal, most famous for being the chief of staff of the Italian army during the first part of World War I."

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: swanq: Thanks for identifying Cadorna more fully. He does appear to be the same man (though, perhaps a bit gaunter) as the one depicted in this Chicago newspaper from May 26, 1916 that I found in the Chronicling America online newspapers: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1916-05-26/ed-... We'll add some information to the description when we next update.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: There's a long entry in Italian in it.wikipedia.org it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luigi_Cadorna This picture was also used in the New York Tribune of June 20, 1915, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-06-20/ed-... Also, this picture (redone as a drawing traced from the photo) is in the Washington Herald of August 8, 1915. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1915-08-08/ed-... "Tall, elegant, lithe, a soldier to his fingertips, every inch a gentleman, a man of the most astounding vivacity and at the same time of the most appealing calm, the one idol of Italy and one of the most brilliant soldiers in the world --- this in a few lines is Count Luigi Cadorna, the generalissimo of the Italian armies which are endeavoring to force their way north through Austria."
